bibl.title: Letter from M.Z. Bair to Henry Rose Carter, April 21, 1922

div1.p: Bair praises the abstracts provided by the Public Health Service. Included is an autograph note from Carter to Mendelsohn.

div1.head: Letter from M.Z. Bair to Henry Rose Carter, April 21, 1922
div1.opener:
Arkansas State Board of Health
LITTLE ROCK
April Twenty-first
1922.
O. W. GARRISON, M. D.
STATE HEALTH OFFICER
Chief Engineer
Dr. H. R. Carter, Ass't Surgeon Gen.,
U. S. Public Health Service,
2121 California Avenue,
Washington, D. C.
My dear Dr. Carter:
div1.p:
We enjoyed very much having Mr. Le Prince with us yesterday, and
at this time, I learned from him that most of your time during the
immediate future will be devoted to the preparation of a manuscript
for a book on Yellow Fever, making it impossible for you to contribute
to the Public Health Abstracts which we receive from the Service.

I consider these Abstracts of immense value, and am sure that I
voice the sentiment of all the State-Sanitary Engineers in expressing
the word, “Appreciation,” to the Service for its action in this matter.
I regret particularly that time will not permit you to continue the Abstracts
on Malaria which I have found of immense value, and I trust you will resume
this work, as soon as you can conveniently do so.
div1.closer:
Respectfully yours, M. Z. Bair
M. Z. Bair, Chief San. Engineer,
STATE BOARD OF HEALTH. MZB:ES
Dear Mr Mendelsohn:
This Appreciation of your work sh'd be pleas-
ant to you.
H. R. Carter
I gave Miss Vaughan- the last time but one I saw her- an
abstract which has not yet appeared. It was primarily on an
article by Hugh Acton. giving account of Hodgson's work

on the effect of aereal humidity on the injection
of Anopheles- i.e. that a certain degree of it was neces-
ry for the development of the Mal Parasite in them.
It was us correlated with Gilknest's tables of the re-
lation of the prevalence of Mal. to - temperature &
w humidity in the Puhrijah. G. has written a-
bout 6 papers-since 1914 - on this subject. long
laborious & by no means illuminating- & this work
of Hodgson's gives the key to the relations
that he has been observing & did not understand
If it be lost, as I presume, no great harm is
done - as Hodgson's work is still progressing
Carter, I am going into Johns Hopkins Hospital
Tuesday.
C
